text: how does Buddhism intersect with science
as we think of science um well I mean if
you look at the history of the
development of Buddhist thought in India
classical India the kind of separation
that you notice in the Western context
between science philosophy and religion
has never really occurred so when you
look at a tradition like Buddhism it's
very you know problematic to classify as
being one of the religious traditions
and it's engagement science is somehow
the engagement between religion and
science and the Western sense because in
Buddhism you have you know certain
aspects of the tradition which are very
scientific empirical evidence is the
most important component of a mode of
inquiry you also have aspects of the
tradition which are clearly religious in
the sense of you know pretending more to
ultimate questions of our existence
meaning purpose and so on and then there
are aspects of the tradition which are
very philosophical we're kind of
argumentation and reasoning is the
primary mode of inquiry so so it's it's
difficult to say that you know because
you know engagement but in Buddhism and
science in the modern sense is an
engagement in religion and science
because Buddhism is in a sense a
complete worldview which had contains
scientific elements philosophical
elements and religious elements and
that's why you sometimes get answers
when Westerners ask people with Eastern
religions we just found this out and you
get the answer we already knew that
sometimes yes or so it seems the Dalai
Lama is very interested in science and
especially in neurology late we've been
hearing about Buddhists related with the
Dalai Lama's you're being in neurology
lab with things attached to their heads
trying to see what a state of Nirvana
looks like in the brain tell us about
this well actually you know there is a
sort of a
to some extent an opportunistic element
in the motivation of Buddhist you know
thinkers like the Dalai Lama engaging
with science because history of Buddhism
has always you know had development of
the Buddhist ideas in relation to its
engagement with other non Buddhist
traditions in India so classically India
was a very intellectually rich place
where Buddhist and non-buddhist like the
vedantic schools and in an I I acres
others were all kind of interacting with
each other so what is happening now for
the Buddhist is in some sense the
continuation of the same story now we
now the kind of the partner in the
dialogue is science because the
scientific worldview is one of the most
influential and dominant worldview and
since Buddhism prizes empiric empiricism
very highly and a political evidence and
reason trymes spiritual authority so in
many aspects of our understanding of
reality in a sense of what the Buddhist
tradition is doing is filling the blanks
as it were by getting the facts from
science
